title: Boston City Council at-large race: Ruthzee Louijeune
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Ruthzee Louijeune, Boston City Council president, highlights affordable housing as a key issue in her at-large race campaign.
Louijeune aims to protect tenants, support public housing, and invest in homebuyers to address Boston's affordability crisis.
She emphasizes transparency, accountability, and public engagement to improve the City Council's public image and trust.

title: Boston City Council at-large Race: Alexandra Valdez
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Alexandra Valdez is running for an at-large seat on the Boston City Council, emphasizing housing as a key issue.
Valdez advocates for building more housing, tenant protections, and homeownership pathways to tackle Boston's housing crisis.
Valdez brings experience from her role as director of Boston's Office of Cultural Affairs and promotes collaboration and transparency.

title: Boston City Council at-large race: Marvin Mathelier
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Marvin Mathelier, a combat veteran, is running for a Boston City Council at-large seat focusing on housing affordability.
Mathelier supports initiatives like expanding affordable rentals, first-time homebuyer pathways, and stabilizing the ONE+Boston program.
He aims to improve City Council accountability by advocating for permanent hybrid meeting access and participatory budgeting expansion.

title: Boston City Council at-large race: Henry Santana
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Henry Santana seeks re-election for Boston City Council at-large, serving since 2023, prioritizing housing affordability.
Santana promotes the $100 million Housing Accelerator Fund aimed at addressing housing equity in Boston.
Santana emphasizes transparency in government, seeking to rebuild public trust in the City Council's actions and decisions.

title: Boston City Council at-large Race: Will Onuoha
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Will Onuoha, a 20-year City Hall veteran, is running for Boston City Council at-large focusing on housing issues.
Onuoha aims to address Boston's housing affordability crisis through bold policies to prevent displacement and expand homeownership.
He brings extensive government experience, having served under four Boston mayors, and promises independent leadership on the Council.

title: Boston City Council at-large race: Erin Murphy
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Erin Murphy has been a Boston City Councilor since 2021 and is running for reelection as an at-large candidate.
Murphy prioritizes addressing Boston's instability issues like affordable housing, reliable services, and education to keep communities rooted.
She focuses on integrity and rebuilding trust in the City Council, emphasizing professionalism, transparency, and accountability.

title: Did you follow the local news this week? Take our Greater Boston news quiz.
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston.com offers a weekly news quiz covering recent stories in Greater Boston.
Peter Chianca is Boston.com's general assignment editor since 2019.
The quiz tests knowledge on current events and trending topics in the local area.

title: Marco Sturmâ€™s faith in Marat Khusnutdinov gets rewarded with Bruins OT winner
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Marat Khusnutdinov scored the overtime goal, leading the Boston Bruins to a 4-3 victory over the Buffalo Sabres.
Khusnutdinov was promoted to the Bruins' top line for the game after impressing coach Marco Sturm with his work ethic.
Despite an uneven season start, Khusnutdinov logged significant ice time and contributed on offense, filling in for injured Elias Lindholm.

title: Why Dan Orlovsky believes Drake Maye is NFL MVP frontrunner
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Drake Maye is considered an NFL MVP frontrunner for his performance with the New England Patriots in the 2025 season.
Maye has led the Patriots to a 6-2 record, completing 75.2% of passes for 2,026 yards and 15 touchdowns.
Former NFL QB Dan Orlovsky argues Maye's impact is significant due to limited talent support in New England.

title: Brookline farm starts free farmers market as Mass. residents brace for SNAP shutdown
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Allandale Farm in Brookline launched a free farmers market due to the government shutdown affecting SNAP benefits.
The market will operate on the first three Thursdays in November at Loring Greenough House in Jamaica Plain.
Gov. Maura Healey announced a new SNAP resource hub and doubled aid to food banks amid the federal shutdown.
